unnormalised: The year was 2015. I remember it vividly. I was sitting in my small apartment in Bangalore, sipping chai and staring at my laptop screen. I'd just quit my comfy IT job at Infosys to pursue this crazy idea: a fintech startup aimed at simplifying payments for small businesses in India. Back then, "fintech" wasn't the buzzword it is today. Most transactions were cash-based. Accepting digital payments was a nightmare for local vendors.
normalised: The year was two thousand and fifteen. I remember it vividly. I was sitting in my small apartment in Bangalore, sipping chai and staring at my laptop screen. I had just quit my comfy I-T job at Infosys to pursue this crazy idea: a fintech startup aimed at simplifying payments for small businesses in India. Back then, "fintech" wasn't the buzzword it is today. Most transactions were cash-based. Accepting digital payments was a nightmare for local vendors.

unnormalised: My co-founder, Rohan, and I named our company "BharatPay". We started with a small team of 5 engineers, crammed into a tiny office space above a bustling street market near Jayanagar. Our initial investment was Rs. 10 lakh, a loan from my parents. We were determined to build a platform that would allow even the smallest chaiwala or kirana store owner to accept payments via UPI, credit cards, and even mobile wallets, all with a single QR code.
normalised: My co-founder, Rohan, and I named our company "BharatPay". We started with a small team of five engineers, crammed into a tiny office space above a bustling street market near Jayanagar. Our initial investment was rupee ten lakh, a loan from my parents. We were determined to build a platform that would allow even the smallest chaiwala or kirana store owner to accept payments via U-P-I, credit cards, and even mobile wallets, all with a single Q-R code.

unnormalised: The first few months were brutal. We spent countless hours convincing shopkeepers to try BharatPay. Many were skeptical. "Why should I trust this 'digital' thing?" they'd ask. "Cash is king!" But we persisted. We explained how BharatPay could help them track their sales, reduce the risk of theft, and reach new customers. We offered incredibly low transaction fees: 0.5%, much lower than what traditional banks charged.

unnormalised: One of our first customers was Sharma Uncle, who ran a small paan shop down the street. He was hesitant, but we convinced him to give it a try. Within a week, his sales increased by 15%. He was amazed. "Beta," he said, "this BharatPay is magic!" Sharma Uncle became our biggest advocate, spreading the word to other shopkeepers in the area.

unnormalised: Slowly but surely, BharatPay started to gain traction. We integrated with major banks like HDFC Bank and ICICI Bank. We launched a mobile app that allowed merchants to manage their accounts and track their transactions in real-time. We partnered with local distributors to reach even the most remote villages.

unnormalised: We faced numerous challenges along the way. There were technical glitches, regulatory hurdles, and fierce competition from established players. But we never gave up. We believed in our vision: to empower small businesses in India with the power of digital payments.

unnormalised: By 2020, BharatPay had become a household name. We were processing over 1 million transactions a day, worth Rs. 50 crores. We had expanded our services to include lending and insurance. We had a team of over 500 employees, spread across offices in Bangalore, Mumbai, and Delhi. The company was valued at $100 million.

The company was valued at dollar one hundred million.

unnormalised: Today, looking back, it feels surreal. From a crazy idea in a small apartment to a leading fintech company, BharatPay has transformed the lives of millions of small business owners across India. It's a testament to the power of innovation, perseverance, and a deep understanding of the Indian market. And it all started with a simple cup of chai and a burning desire to make a difference.
